article:
]] The 'pawn' ( ââ ) is the most numerous
 piece in the game of chess, and in most circumstances, also the weakest. It
 historically represents infantry, or more particularly, armed peasants or
 pikemen. Each player begins a game of chess with eight pawns, one on each
 square of the rank immediately in front of the other pieces. (In algebraic
 notation, the white pawns start on a2, b2, c2, ..., h2, while black pawns start
 on a7, b7, c7, ..., h7.)

Individual pawns are referred to by the file on which they stand. For example,
one speaks of "White's f-pawn" or "Black's b-pawn", or less commonly (using
descriptive notation), "White's king bishop pawn" or "Black's queen knight
pawn". It is also common to refer to a [[rook pawn]], meaning any pawn on the a-
or h-file, a [[knight pawn]] (on the b- or g-file), a [[bishop pawn]] (on the c-
or f-file), a [[list of chess terms#Queen pawn|queen pawn]] (on the d-file), a
[[list of chess terms#King pawn|king pawn]] (on the e-file), and a [[central
pawn]] (on either the d- or e-file).
